summary:
The case of Boner v. the United Kingdom (Application no. 18711/91) concerns a breach of Article 6 para. 3 (c) of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) by the United Kingdom. The applicant, Mr. Anthony Boner, was arrested and charged with murder in 1989. He was denied access to a lawyer during the initial 24-hour period following his arrest, contrary to the United Kingdom's domestic law and the ECHR. The applicant claimed that this denial of access to a lawyer breached his right to a fair trial under Article 6 para. 3 (c) of the ECHR.

The case was referred to the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) by the European Commission of Human Rights and the Government of the United Kingdom. The applicant designated a lawyer to represent him, and the President of the Court decided to hear the case together with another case, Maxwell v. the United Kingdom. The Chamber was constituted, and the parties were consulted on the organisation of the proceedings. The applicant and the Government submitted their written memorials, and the Commission did not submit written observations in reply. The hearing took place on 18 April 1994, and the Court heard addresses by the parties and replied to their questions.

The judges considered that the facts of the case disclosed a breach by the United Kingdom of its obligations under Article 6 para. 3 (c) of the ECHR. The judges held that the denial of access to a lawyer during the initial 24-hour period following the applicant's arrest was a breach of his right to a fair trial, as it did not allow him to consult with a lawyer and prepare his defence. The judges linked the complaints of the applicant with those of the Government by considering the United Kingdom's domestic law and the ECHR. The judges held that the United Kingdom's domestic law, which allowed for the denial of access to a lawyer during the initial 24-hour period, was incompatible with the ECHR. The judges also considered that the applicant's right to a fair trial under Article 6 para. 3 (c) of the ECHR was a fundamental right that was essential to the proper administration of justice.

The judges emphasized that the denial of access to a lawyer during the initial 24-hour period following the applicant's arrest had a significant impact on the way the norms and standards of the ECHR were applied. The judges held that the United Kingdom's domestic law, which allowed for the denial of access to a lawyer during the initial 24-hour period, was a breach of the ECHR and that the applicant's right to a fair trial was not respected.
